elements.content: Americium oxalate single crystals, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O, were prepared by in situ oxalic acid generation by slow hydrolysis of the diester. Their structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and was solved by the direct methods and Fourier difference techniques. The structure (space group P21/c, a = 11.184(4) Å, b = 9.489(4) Å, c = 10.234(4) Å, β = 114.308(8)°, Z = 2) consists of layers formed by six-membered rings of actinide metals connected through oxalate ions. The americium atoms are nine-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from three bidentate oxalate ligands and three water molecules. The distances within the coordination sphere as well as infrared and Raman spectra of several isostructural lanthanide (Ce­(III), Pr­(III), Nd­(III), Sm­(III), Gd­(III)) and actinide (Pu­(III), Am­(III)) oxalates were compared to evaluate the similarities and the differences between the two series.

The americium atoms are nine-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from three bidentate oxalate ligands and three water molecules. The distances within the coordination sphere as well as infrared and Raman spectra of several isostructural lanthanide (Ce(III), Pr(III), Nd(III), Sm(III), Gd(III)) and actinide (Pu(III), Am(III)) oxalates were compared to evaluate the similarities and the differences between the two series.

elements.content: The structure of americium oxalate, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O, was solved using single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Isotypic structures have already been described for lanthanides­(III) and plutonium­(III). The comparison of this structure along the lanthanide and actinide series and between the two f-blocks gives some interesting information concerning the bonding of the oxalate with the metallic cation. The first hypotheses rest upon coordination sphere distances and infrared and Raman spectroscopic characterizations.

elements.content: Actinide oxalates are important precursors of oxides used in many nuclear applications but also in non-nuclear ones. Pu­(IV) and Pu­(III) oxalates are well-known intermediates that precipitate in the treatment of the spent nuclear fuels in order to retrieve plutonium from wastes with excellent yields for recycling purpose. These single Pu oxalate salts are indeed very insoluble and can be easily calcined into PuO2, conventionally used in the manufacturing processes of mixed oxide fuels for either light water reactors or fast neutron reactors. 238PuO2 is also a strategic material for space applications. The radioactive decay of 238Pu supplies heat for radioisotope thermal generators which have provided electricity for many space exploration satellites and vehicles (such as Voyager, Cassini, Galileo, and more recently the Mars rover Curiosity). 238PuO2 has been synthesized mainly after precipitating Pu­(III) oxalate, Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O. Surprisingly, the structure of this compound was fully elucidated only recently, despite many prior studies and attempts, and the single Pu­(IV) oxalate structure Pu­(C2O4)2·​6H2O, the key intermediate of the recycling treatment of the spent fuels for more than 50 years, has still never been fully described from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) acquisition. Regarding americium oxalates, the structural database is even poorer, despite some quite important technological and academic issues. Single Am oxalate is indeed the main intermediate used to produce AmO2 for specific applications (ionization smoke detector, neutron source). Am is an important element in the 5f series, being one of the last “light” actinides, which then motivates precise Am structural studies to compare 4f/5f elements’ behavior using, e.g., analogous coordination polymers. Currently, due to the shortage of 238Pu supplies in many countries, 241Am oxide is being considered as the isotope of choice for heat sources in future satellites or other space vehicles, particularly in European projects (mainly from the European Space Agency). The primary route to separate, purify, and convert americium into oxide is via precipitation of Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O. Depending on the manufacturing route for Am oxide materials, the shape and size of the crystals of the precipitate need to be controlled. Unfortunately, the precise structure of Am oxalate has also never been fully elucidated, namely using single-crystal XRD.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Actinide oxalates are important precursors of oxides used in many nuclear applications but also in non-nuclear ones. Pu(IV) and Pu(III) oxalates are well-known intermediates that precipitate in the treatment of the spent nuclear fuels in order to retrieve plutonium from wastes with excellent yields for recycling purpose. These single Pu oxalate salts are indeed very insoluble and can be easily calcined into PuO2, conventionally used in the manufacturing processes of mixed oxide fuels for either light water reactors or fast neutron reactors. 238PuO2 is also a strategic material for space applications. The radioactive decay of 238Pu supplies heat for radioisotope thermal generators which have provided electricity for many space exploration satellites and vehicles (such as Voyager, Cassini, Galileo, and more recently the Mars rover Curiosity). 238PuO2 has been synthesized mainly after precipitating Pu(III) oxalate, Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O. Surprisingly, the structure of this compound was fully elucidated only recently, despite many prior studies and attempts, and the single Pu(IV) oxalate structure Pu(C2O4)2⋅6H2O, the key intermediate of the recycling treatment of the spent fuels for more than 50 years, has still never been fully described from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) acquisition. Regarding americium oxalates, the structural database is even poorer, despite some quite important technological and academic issues. Single Am oxalate is indeed the main intermediate used to produce AmO2 for specific applications (ionization smoke detector, neutron source). Am is an important element in the 5f series, being one of the last "light" actinides, which then motivates precise Am structural studies to compare 4f/5f elements' behavior using, e.g., analogous coordination polymers. Currently, due to the shortage of 238Pu supplies in many countries, 241Am oxide is being considered as the isotope of choice for heat sources in future satellites or other space vehicles, particularly in European projects (mainly from the European Space Agency). The primary route to separate, purify, and convert americium into oxide is via precipitation of Am2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O. Depending on the manufacturing route for Am oxide materials, the shape and size of the crystals of the precipitate need to be controlled. Unfortunately, the precise structure of Am oxalate has also never been fully elucidated, namely using single-crystal XRD.

elements.content: Prior studies of americium oxalates indeed are limited to powder compounds. The first tan-brown oxalate hepta­hydrate, Am2­(C2O4)3·​7H2O, was synthesized by Markin in 1958 by precipitation from Am­(III) aqueous solution. The first structural study was realized by Weigel in 1967; the solid was characterized by comparison of its powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern with that of the neodymium oxalate deca­hydrate, Nd2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O. The first lattice parameters were thus proposed: a = 11.19 Å, b = 9.53 Å, c = 10.24 Å, and β = 114.4°. More than a decade later, Zubarev worked on double M+–Am­(III) oxalate compounds, MAm­(C2O4)2·​nH2O, with M = NH4, Na, K, Cs, but without single-crystal structure determination. More generally, there are very few americium­(III) structure determinations from single-crystal data reported in the literature. Considering only organic ligands, seven structures were completely described (based on a search of the CCDC). One study concerned nitrogen poly­aromatic molecules, whereas the others focused on harder ligands with oxygen donors: carboxylate groups, α-hydroxy-carboxylate molecules, and amino-carboxylate ligands, with among them the dipicolinate motifs.

More generally, there are very few americium(III) structure determinations from single-crystal data reported in the literature. Considering only organic ligands, seven structures were completely described (based on a search of the CCDC). One study concerned nitrogen polyaromatic molecules, whereas the others focused on harder ligands with oxygen donors: carboxylate groups, α-hydroxy-carboxylate molecules, and amino-carboxylate ligands, with among them the dipicolinate motifs.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the first crystal structure determination of the americium oxalate, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O (A), and compare it to isomorphous compounds already described in the literature, Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​3H2O and Ln2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O. The description of the second oxalate structure of the actinide series (after the plutonium) gives the opportunity to compare the behavior of the two f-element series. The distances and bonding between the metallic cation and oxalate ions are more particularly discussed on the basis of crystal data and infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopies, used as local probes. In order to study the oxalate–metal bonding, we synthesized pure Ln2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, with Ln = Pr (B), Nd (C), Sm (D), and Gd (E) (light lanthanides with ionic radii close to those of americium and plutonium), using the same crystal growth method as for americium oxalate. Single crystals of Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​3H2O (F) were synthesized and fully characterized as well. For actinide compounds, pure powders of Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O (A) and Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O (F) were also prepared by precipitation.

The description of the second oxalate structure of the actinide series (after the plutonium) gives the opportunity to compare the behavior of the two f-element series. The distances and bonding between the metallic cation and oxalate ions are more particularly discussed on the basis of crystal data and infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopies, used as local probes. In order to study the oxalate-metal bonding, we synthesized pure Ln2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, with Ln = Pr (B), Nd (C), Sm (D), and Gd (E) (light lanthanides with ionic radii close to those of americium and plutonium), using the same crystal growth method as for americium oxalate. Single crystals of Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅3H2O (F) were synthesized and fully characterized as well. For actinide compounds, pure powders of Am2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O (A) and Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O (F) were also prepared by precipitation.

elements.content: All experiments on trans-uranium elements were conducted in the Atalante facility (CEA Marcoule, France), in a laboratory dedicated to the structural study of these highly radioactive elements. All experiments were carried out with approved safety operating procedures in a negative-pressure glovebox. 241Am (t 1/2 = 432.2 years) is not favorable to the use of slow and controlled crystallization methods and to crystal preservation due to its relative high specific activity. It is thus necessary to analyze single crystals immediately after their synthesis. Americium­(III) solution was prepared by dissolving the dioxide AmO2 with concentrated HNO3 (VWR) in glovebox. Plutonium­(III) solution (isotopic purity >90% 239Pu) was prepared via reduction by hydrazinium nitrate (N2H5 +, NO3 –, 5 equiv) of a plutonium­(IV) solution, prepared by dissolving PuO2 in concentrated HNO3. Am­(III) is stable in nitric acid solution, but hydrazinium nitrate had to be used as an anti-nitrous agent to stabilize plutonium at its lowest oxidation state, Pu­(III). The concentration of actinide in each stock solution is close to 0.1 mol·​L–1. The concentration, purity, and oxidation state were essentially determined by UV–vis spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Safety

All experiments on trans-uranium elements were conducted in the Atalante facility (CEA Marcoule, France), in a laboratory dedicated to the structural study of these highly radioactive elements. All experiments were carried out with approved safety operating procedures in a negative-pressure glovebox. 241Am (t 1/2 = 432.2 years) is not favorable to the use of slow and controlled crystallization methods and to crystal preservation due to its relative high specific activity. It is thus necessary to analyze single crystals immediately after their synthesis. Americium(III) solution was prepared by dissolving the dioxide AmO2 with concentrated HNO3 (VWR) in glovebox. Plutonium(III) solution (isotopic purity >90% 239Pu) was prepared via reduction by hydrazinium nitrate (N2H5 +, NO3 -, 5 equiv) of a plutonium(IV) solution, prepared by dissolving PuO2 in concentrated HNO3. Am(III) is stable in nitric acid solution, but hydrazinium nitrate had to be used as an anti-nitrous agent to stabilize plutonium at its lowest oxidation state, Pu(III). The concentration of actinide in each stock solution is close to 0.1 mol⋅L-1. The concentration, purity, and oxidation state were essentially determined by UV-vis spectroscopy.

elements.content: Butanol, ethanol, diethyl oxalate, and dibutyl oxalate (>99% purity) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Oxalic acid was used in its dihydrated form, H2C2O4·​2H2O (VWR). Hydrazinium nitrate was prepared before being added to the plutonium solution by neutralizing 100% hydrazine monohydrate with concentrated nitric acid (HNO3 68%). This reaction is very exothermic, and cautions have to be taken (fume hood, ice bath). Once the solution is prepared, its mixing with other reagents does not require specific care (apart from its CMR toxicity).
elements.clean_text: Butanol, ethanol, diethyl oxalate, and dibutyl oxalate (>99% purity) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Oxalic acid was used in its dihydrated form, H2C2O4⋅2H2O (VWR). Hydrazinium nitrate was prepared before being added to the plutonium solution by neutralizing 100% hydrazine monohydrate with concentrated nitric acid (HNO3 68%). This reaction is very exothermic, and cautions have to be taken (fume hood, ice bath). Once the solution is prepared, its mixing with other reagents does not require specific care (apart from its CMR toxicity).

elements.content: Crystals of americium oxalate were synthesized according to previously reported method using dibutyl oxalate as oxalic acid precursor. The americium solution (masse Am = 4 mg) was added to a mixture of butanol and dibutyl oxalate according to the chemical conditions gathered in . The mixture was left 1 day before crystallization. For unknown reasons, in contrast to lanthanides (see below), the synthesis with diethyl oxalate as precursor did not lead to single crystals.

The americium solution (masse Am = 4 mg) was added to a mixture of butanol and dibutyl oxalate according to the chemical conditions gathered in . The mixture was left 1 day before crystallization. For unknown reasons, in contrast to lanthanides (see below), the synthesis with diethyl oxalate as precursor did not lead to single crystals.

Crystals of lanthanide oxalate were prepared using the same synthesis method but starting from diethyl oxalate. The lanthanide nitrate was dissolved directly in 65% concentrated nitric acid. This solution was then added to a mixture of ethanol and diethyl oxalate according to the chemical conditions gathered in . For all the studied lanthanide cations, this synthesis leads to a single-phase solid made of large single crystals (80–200 μm).

elements.content: Crystals of plutonium­(III) oxalate were grown using a method based on reagents’ diffusion using a triple cell. The nitric acidity was set at 1.5 mol·​L–1 in the three compartments: 0.025 mol·​L–1 of plutonium­(III) nitric solution was placed in one external compartment, whereas 0.126 g of oxalic acid large crystals was placed in the opposite compartment in order to allow progressive dissolution of the solid. Hydrazinium nitrate (0.2 mol·​L–1) was added in the three compartments to limit the Pu­(III) re-oxidation.
elements.clean_text:
Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O (F)

Crystals of plutonium(III) oxalate were grown using a method based on reagents' diffusion using a triple cell. The nitric acidity was set at 1.5 mol⋅L-1 in the three compartments: 0.025 mol⋅L-1 of plutonium(III) nitric solution was placed in one external compartment, whereas 0.126 g of oxalic acid large crystals was placed in the opposite compartment in order to allow progressive dissolution of the solid. Hydrazinium nitrate (0.2 mol⋅L-1) was added in the three compartments to limit the Pu(III) re-oxidation.

elements.content: The use of the as-described crystal growth methods leads to multi-phase solids for the americium (A) and plutonium (F) oxalates. So, both of the compounds were also prepared by oxalic precipitation in order to perform IR spectroscopic analyses on a sufficient amount of pure-phase solid. The AnIII 2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O (An = Am, Pu) oxalate precipitates were synthesized by mixing the An­(III) solution (masse Am = 0.5 mg or masse Pu = 20 mg) with a concentrated H2C2O4·​2H2O solution (with a slight excess of oxalic acid, 0.2 mol·​L–1) in a 1 mol·​L–1 nitric medium. The resulting crystallized powders were filtered off, washed with ethanol/​water (90/10), and dried at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: The use of the as-described crystal growth methods leads to multi-phase solids for the americium (A) and plutonium (F) oxalates. So, both of the compounds were also prepared by oxalic precipitation in order to perform IR spectroscopic analyses on a sufficient amount of pure-phase solid. The AnIII 2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O (An = Am, Pu) oxalate precipitates were synthesized by mixing the An(III) solution (masse Am = 0.5 mg or masse Pu = 20 mg) with a concentrated H2C2O4⋅2H2O solution (with a slight excess of oxalic acid, 0.2 mol⋅L-1) in a 1 mol⋅L-1 nitric medium. The resulting crystallized powders were filtered off, washed with ethanol/water (90/10), and dried at room temperature.

elements.content: The apparatus is not inside a glovebox. To prevent americium and plutonium health hazards, each crystal was mounted on MicroMount patented by MiTeGen, inserted into a goniometer base. A MicroRT capillary was then drawn over the sample and onto the base, where it was sealed by adhesive. The single-crystal XRD intensities were measured on a Nonius four-circle diffractometer equipped with an Apex II detector coupled device at 150 K using a 600 series cryo­stream cooler (Oxford Cryosystem). The instrument is equipped with a fine-focus Mo-target X-ray tube (λ = 0.71073 Å) operated at 1500 W. A hemi­sphere of data was collected using phi and omega scans, with 20 and 30 s frame exposure for americium and plutonium, respectively, and 0.5° frame widths. Intensities were extracted from the collected frames using the program SAINTPlus. The unit cell parameters were refined from the complete data set, and an empirical absorption correction was performed using the SADABS procedure. The structure determination and refinements were performed with SHELX-97 software. The heavy atoms were located by direct methods, while the remaining atoms were found from successive Fourier map analyses. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located, and their positions and anisotropic displacement parameters were refined. The thermal agitation of the water molecules is quite high because of (i) water’s relatively small electronic density compared to actinide and (ii) the deterioration of the crystal during the data collection, probably due to the actinide’s specific activity. The phenomenon is accentuated for plutonium, for which data were collected at room temperature instead of 150 K because of the cryosystem failure. The water molecules are likely the first to undergo radiation damage, as they are very sensitive to radiolysis. This could also be one reason explaining the relatively high residual electron density and the difficulty in determining and setting the occupation rate of these molecules. As a consequence, the location of the hydrogen atoms of the inter­space water molecules could not be determined. For the americium structure, the hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecule were found on different Fourier maps but refined with distances and angle constraints. The crystal data and details of the final refinement for both plutonium and americium structures are reported in and in the Supporting Information. In this paper, the structure of plutonium oxalate is not described, as it has already been reported. Nevertheless, the comparison of the distances in the second part of this paper uses the bond lengths of this present structure determination.

PXRD patterns were obtained with a Bruker AXS D8 diffractometer (curved position-sensitive detector) using Cu radiation (Kα1 = 1.5406 Å; Kα2 = 1.5444 Å) and mounted with a LynxEye angular detector. The scan step was fixed to 0.02° with a counting time of 1 s·​step–1 from 5° to 60°. Silicon was added to samples as an internal standard to calibrate the angular positions of the observed XRD lines. The actinide oxalate compounds and silicon were mixed with an epoxy resin to prevent contamination spreading, as the diffractometer is outside glovebox. Kα2 stripping of the Cu radiation according to the Rachinger method, and the baseline and angle shift corrections were performed by empirical calculations and EVA software.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

PXRD patterns were obtained with a Bruker AXS D8 diffractometer (curved position-sensitive detector) using Cu radiation (Kα1 = 1.5406 Å; Kα2 = 1.5444 Å) and mounted with a LynxEye angular detector. The scan step was fixed to 0.02° with a counting time of 1 s⋅step-1 from 5° to 60°. Silicon was added to samples as an internal standard to calibrate the angular positions of the observed XRD lines. The actinide oxalate compounds and silicon were mixed with an epoxy resin to prevent contamination spreading, as the diffractometer is outside glovebox. Kα2 stripping of the Cu radiation according to the Rachinger method, and the baseline and angle shift corrections were performed by empirical calculations and EVA software.

elements.content: A Jobin-Yvon LabRam Raman 242 spectrometer was used in conjunction with a nuclearized superhead (Optique Peter, Lyon, France) mounted on a support with an objective turret (10×, 20×, and 50×). A YAG laser (532 nm) with output power adjustable from 20 to 120 mW with a variable filter was used to provide low-excitation-beam power levels. The superhead was mounted in a glovebox, while the Raman spectrometer and laser were installed outside the glovebox with a fiber-optic signal transmission line. The analyses were carried out on an average of five selected single crystals. The microscope objective used for oxalate single-crystal analyses was 20×.
elements.clean_text:
Raman Spectroscopy

A Jobin-Yvon LabRam Raman 242 spectrometer was used in conjunction with a nuclearized superhead (Optique Peter, Lyon, France) mounted on a support with an objective turret (10×, 20×, and 50×). A YAG laser (532 nm) with output power adjustable from 20 to 120 mW with a variable filter was used to provide low-excitation-beam power levels. The superhead was mounted in a glovebox, while the Raman spectrometer and laser were installed outside the glovebox with a fiber-optic signal transmission line. The analyses were carried out on an average of five selected single crystals. The microscope objective used for oxalate single-crystal analyses was 20×.

elements.content: The actinide solutions were analyzed by UV–vis absorption spectroscopy using a Cary 5000 UV spectro­photometer (Agilent) between 350 and 900 nm. Actinide oxidation state in the precipitates was investigated in a glovebox using a Hitachi U-3000 spectro­photometer equipped with an integration sphere for reflection measurements.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Visible Spectroscopy

The actinide solutions were analyzed by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy using a Cary 5000 UV spectrophotometer (Agilent) between 350 and 900 nm. Actinide oxidation state in the precipitates was investigated in a glovebox using a Hitachi U-3000 spectrophotometer equipped with an integration sphere for reflection measurements.

elements.content: The solids were analyzed with a dual-channel FT-IR spectro­photometer from Bruker Optics, Equinox 55. It is equipped with an ATR module which enables solid samples to be examined directly without further preparation. For americium­(III) and plutonium­(III) oxalates, the spectra were acquired from the single-phase precipitates. For lanthanide­(III) oxalates, as no secondary phase was formed during crystal growth, single crystals were analyzed directly.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

The solids were analyzed with a dual-channel FT-IR spectrophotometer from Bruker Optics, Equinox 55. It is equipped with an ATR module which enables solid samples to be examined directly without further preparation. For americium(III) and plutonium(III) oxalates, the spectra were acquired from the single-phase precipitates. For lanthanide(III) oxalates, as no secondary phase was formed during crystal growth, single crystals were analyzed directly.

elements.content:
displays the americium oxalate single crystals (A) as light brown prisms, 20 μm long. Transparent single crystals, probably of oxalic acid, make the solid non-single-phase.

The presence of americium within the crystals was confirmed by comparing the UV–vis spectrum of the solid to that of a nitric acid americium­(III) solution (). The same overall shape, characterized by the two bands at 503 nm (7F0 → 5L6) and 811 nm (7F0 → 7F6), confirms the presence of americium, despite a broadening of the major peak already discussed by Runde. The small shift of the wavelengths in the solid compared to the solution is due to different Am­(III) coordination modes and thus to different environments.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Americium Oxalate Characterization

  displays the americium oxalate single crystals (A) as light brown prisms, 20 μm long. Transparent single crystals, probably of oxalic acid, make the solid non-single-phase.

The presence of americium within the crystals was confirmed by comparing the UV-vis spectrum of the solid to that of a nitric acid americium(III) solution (). The same overall shape, characterized by the two bands at 503 nm (7F0 → 5L6) and 811 nm (7F0 → 7F6), confirms the presence of americium, despite a broadening of the major peak already discussed by Runde. The small shift of the wavelengths in the solid compared to the solution is due to different Am(III) coordination modes and thus to different environments.

elements.content: The structure of the americium oxalate was determined using single-crystal XRD. The unit cell parameters, a = 11.188(1) Å, b = 9.489(1) Å, c = 10.234(1) Å, and β = 114.308(8)°, are quite similar to those determined by Weigel and Ter Meer in 1967, starting from powder compound on considering an analogy with the neodymium oxalate (a = 11.19 Å, b = 9.53 Å, c = 10.24 Å, and β = 114.4°). One can notice a slightly higher value for just the b parameter.

The unit cell parameters, a = 11.188(1) Å, b = 9.489(1) Å, c = 10.234(1) Å, and β = 114.308(8)°, are quite similar to those determined by Weigel and Ter Meer in 1967, starting from powder compound on considering an analogy with the neodymium oxalate (a = 11.19 Å, b = 9.53 Å, c = 10.24 Å, and β = 114.4°). One can notice a slightly higher value for just the b parameter.

elements.content: The structure of the americium­(III) oxalate, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O, was solved in the space group P21/c. It contains three independent bidentate oxalate ligands coordinated to one metallic cation. The coordination sphere is completed by three water oxygen atoms (O7, O8, O9, ). The americium cations are located at the center of tricapped trigonal prisms. Surprisingly, the capped positions are not occupied by the three water molecules but by three oxygen atoms from three independent oxalate ions leading to distorted AmO9 polyhedra. The polyhedron is nevertheless identical to the lanthanide and plutonium ones.
elements.clean_text: The structure of the americium(III) oxalate, Am2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅4H2O, was solved in the space group P21/c. It contains three independent bidentate oxalate ligands coordinated to one metallic cation. The coordination sphere is completed by three water oxygen atoms (O7, O8, O9, ). The americium cations are located at the center of tricapped trigonal prisms. Surprisingly, the capped positions are not occupied by the three water molecules but by three oxygen atoms from three independent oxalate ions leading to distorted AmO9 polyhedra. The polyhedron is nevertheless identical to the lanthanide and plutonium ones.

elements.content: Coordination of americium­(III) by three bidendate oxalate ligands and three water molecules (left) and the oxygen polyhedron, described as a distorted tricapped trigonal prism (right) in structure A.
elements.clean_text: 3  Coordination of americium(III) by three bidendate oxalate ligands and three water molecules (left) and the oxygen polyhedron, described as a distorted tricapped trigonal prism (right) in structure A.

elements.content: The bond lengths and angles for the oxalate ligands [the distance C–O ranges from 1.242(9) to 1.269(9) Å; C–C are between 1.524 and 1.546 Å; the angles O–C–O are 125.0(6)°, 126.2(7)°, and 125.1(7)°; and O–C–C vary from 116.4 (7)° to 118.0(8)°] are in good agreement with the values reported by Hahn for oxalate compounds (C–O = 1.24 Å, C–C = 1.55 Å, O–C–O = 125°, and O–C–C = 117°) (see Table S1). The Am–O distances are between 2.470 and 2.568 Å for the oxalate oxygen atoms and 2.473 and 2.527 Å for the water molecules. The average oxalate ligand distance, 2.507(6) Å, is slightly longer than the average value for the water molecules, 2.495(5) Å. This is often observed in complexes in which complexation by hard anions such as oxalate and carbonate allows a wide variation of other bond distances in the coordination polyhedron. The Am–O distances are close to those found in the americium citrate structure previously described in the literature, with bonds in the range 2.420–2.543 Å. The small shift between the two structures can be due to strong steric effects of the polydentate citrate groups.

The Am-O distances are between 2.470 and 2.568 Å for the oxalate oxygen atoms and 2.473 and 2.527 Å for the water molecules. The average oxalate ligand distance, 2.507(6) Å, is slightly longer than the average value for the water molecules, 2.495(5) Å. This is often observed in complexes in which complexation by hard anions such as oxalate and carbonate allows a wide variation of other bond distances in the coordination polyhedron. The Am-O distances are close to those found in the americium citrate structure previously described in the literature, with bonds in the range 2.420-2.543 Å. The small shift between the two structures can be due to strong steric effects of the polydentate citrate groups.

elements.content: Bridging bis-bidentate μ2-oxalate ions connect adjacent actinides to form six-membered rings and a honeycomb 2D arrangement stacked along the b-axis (). The pseudohexagonal or elliptic aperture, 8.1 Å width and 9.8 Å height, is in the same range as the aperture described by Runde for the isostructural compound Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​3H2O (8.2 × 9.3 Å). The distance between two actinide atoms from adjacent layers is 4.756(4) Å. The Am–Am distances range from 6.41 to 6.57 Å, more settled than the Pu ones from 6.18 to 6.58 Å, and the Am–Am–Am angles, 104.21°, 119.30°, and 130.57°, are identical to the plutonium ones, 104.59°, 119.39°, and 129.99°.
elements.clean_text: Bridging bis-bidentate μ2-oxalate ions connect adjacent actinides to form six-membered rings and a honeycomb 2D arrangement stacked along the b-axis (). The pseudohexagonal or elliptic aperture, 8.1 Å width and 9.8 Å height, is in the same range as the aperture described by Runde for the isostructural compound Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅3H2O (8.2 × 9.3 Å). The distance between two actinide atoms from adjacent layers is 4.756(4) Å. The Am-Am distances range from 6.41 to 6.57 Å, more settled than the Pu ones from 6.18 to 6.58 Å, and the Am-Am-Am angles, 104.21°, 119.30°, and 130.57°, are identical to the plutonium ones, 104.59°, 119.39°, and 129.99°.

elements.content: Free water molecules are located in the interlayer space and within the aperture of the honeycomb-like layers. They are all disordered on two sites with partial occupations. Four non-coordinated water molecules were identified which is one more than for the plutonium­(III) oxalate. The number of water molecules in the interlayer space is still under discussion in the literature, and several papers give a range between 2.5 and 4.5 water molecules. Structures of lanthanum oxalates were described with 3.2, 3.5, or 4 water molecules, whereas for smaller lanthanides, like gadolinium, only 2.5 molecules were found. For neodymium oxalate, the structure was solved with 4 or 4.5 water molecules. Moreover, the use of butanol during synthesis may have contributed to the presence of alcohol within the structure, but the structure determination attempts considering disordered alcohol did not lead to satisfactory results.

elements.content: Over several decades, it has become obvious that the simplistic description of the 5f elements as being the same as that of lanthanides is a rough idea. Indeed, considering purely ionic interactions based on examination of the ionic radii, one would expect a similar behavior between the two series, but they are known to vary. With two solved isotructural actinide compounds, it is now possible to compare the behavior of the two f-element series through the observations of the bond lengths and IR and Raman spectroscopies. Only light lanthanides with ionic radii close to those of americium and plutonium (Ce­(III), Pr­(III), Nd­(III), Sm­(III), Gd­(III)) with isomorphous structures were considered for these comparisons. For heavier lanthanides, a modification of the oxalate structure, well-known transition along the lanthanide series, would make the comparison incorrect. To perform the physicochemical analyses and compare the results, single-phase lanthanide oxalates, Ln2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, americium oxalate, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, and plutonium­(III) oxalate, Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, are needed, so all the solids were characterized by means of PXRD before spectroscopic analyses and comparison.
elements.clean_text:
Lanthanide-Actinide Comparison: Distances and Raman and IR Spectroscopies

Over several decades, it has become obvious that the simplistic description of the 5f elements as being the same as that of lanthanides is a rough idea. Indeed, considering purely ionic interactions based on examination of the ionic radii, one would expect a similar behavior between the two series, but they are known to vary. With two solved isotructural actinide compounds, it is now possible to compare the behavior of the two f-element series through the observations of the bond lengths and IR and Raman spectroscopies. Only light lanthanides with ionic radii close to those of americium and plutonium (Ce(III), Pr(III), Nd(III), Sm(III), Gd(III)) with isomorphous structures were considered for these comparisons. For heavier lanthanides, a modification of the oxalate structure, well-known transition along the lanthanide series, would make the comparison incorrect. To perform the physicochemical analyses and compare the results, single-phase lanthanide oxalates, Ln2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, americium oxalate, Am2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, and plutonium(III) oxalate, Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, are needed, so all the solids were characterized by means of PXRD before spectroscopic analyses and comparison.

elements.content: The attendance of colorless crystals within the americium oxalate single crystals prohibits the direct spectroscopic analyses. Americium oxalate was thus precipitate according to mastered and reproducible oxalic precipitation. Although the too small amount of precipitated americium oxalate recovered from the oxalic precipitation did not enable PXRD analysis, the formation of another phase is unlikely in these specific chemical conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Trivalent Metal Oxalates

The attendance of colorless crystals within the americium oxalate single crystals prohibits the direct spectroscopic analyses. Americium oxalate was thus precipitate according to mastered and reproducible oxalic precipitation. Although the too small amount of precipitated americium oxalate recovered from the oxalic precipitation did not enable PXRD analysis, the formation of another phase is unlikely in these specific chemical conditions.

elements.content: The weak intensity and the poor resolution of the pattern are due to the small amount of solid. The structures of the plutonium hexa­hydrated oxalate and the mixed-valence plutonium tetragonal oxalate, respectively Pu­(C2O4)2·​6H2O and (M+)2+x PuIII x PuIV 2‑x ­(C2O4)5·​nH2O, have not been fully determined from single-crystal XRD up to now because of strong difficulties to grow the corresponding single crystals. Therefore, to identify the corresponding structures in powder XRD pattern, calculated patterns of isomorphous oxalates, U­(C2O4)2·​6H2O and (M+)2+x LnIII x UIV 2‑x ­(C2O4)5·​nH2O, were used. As a result, the signatures of oxalate phases that pertain to (i) a trivalent element deca­hydrate series, PuIII 2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, (ii) a tetravalent actinide oxalate hexa­hydrate, Pu­(C2O4)2·​6H2O, and (iii) a tetragonal-type oxalate phase, (M+)2+x PuIII x PuIV 2‑x ­(C2O4)5·​nH2O, were identified on the XRD pattern. Our previous experiments concerning oxalate actinide systems and the specific shape and color of each single crystal type reasonably suggest that the blue crystals correspond to the plutonium­(III) oxalate deca­hydrate, Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O. The nature of the blue crystals was confirmed by single-crystal XRD, with refined lattice parameters a = 11,214(1) Å, b = 9.605(1) Å, c = 10.287(1) Å, and β = 114.40(1)°, close to those previously found by Runde et al. (a = 11.246(3) Å, b = 9.590(3) Å, c = 10.315(3) Å, and β = 114.47(1)°). The solid being multi-phase, the synthesis of pure PuIII 2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O was accomplished by precipitation (a).
elements.clean_text: The weak intensity and the poor resolution of the pattern are due to the small amount of solid. The structures of the plutonium hexahydrated oxalate and the mixed-valence plutonium tetragonal oxalate, respectively Pu(C2O4)2⋅6H2O and (M+)2+x PuIII  x PuIV 2-x (C2O4)5⋅nH2O, have not been fully determined from single-crystal XRD up to now because of strong difficulties to grow the corresponding single crystals. Therefore, to identify the corresponding structures in powder XRD pattern, calculated patterns of isomorphous oxalates, U(C2O4)2⋅6H2O and (M+)2+x LnIII  x UIV 2-x (C2O4)5⋅nH2O, were used. As a result, the signatures of oxalate phases that pertain to (i) a trivalent element decahydrate series, PuIII 2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, (ii) a tetravalent actinide oxalate hexahydrate, Pu(C2O4)2⋅6H2O, and (iii) a tetragonal-type oxalate phase, (M+)2+x PuIII  x PuIV 2-x (C2O4)5⋅nH2O, were identified on the XRD pattern. Our previous experiments concerning oxalate actinide systems and the specific shape and color of each single crystal type reasonably suggest that the blue crystals correspond to the plutonium(III) oxalate decahydrate, Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O. The nature of the blue crystals was confirmed by single-crystal XRD, with refined lattice parameters a = 11,214(1) Å, b = 9.605(1) Å, c = 10.287(1) Å, and β = 114.40(1)°, close to those previously found by Runde et al. (a = 11.246(3) Å, b = 9.590(3) Å, c = 10.315(3) Å, and β = 114.47(1)°). The solid being multi-phase, the synthesis of pure PuIII 2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O was accomplished by precipitation (a).

shows the trend of the metal oxygen distances within the coordination sphere versus the ionic radii. There is no single work concerning ionic radii determination both on trivalent actinides and lanthanides with a coordination number (CN) of 9. On one hand, Shannon reported ionic radii for all the studied lanthanides but not for nine-fold-coordinated trivalent plutonium and americium. On the other hand, David et al. reported ionic radii of actinides and some lanthanides but not those used for this study. Pu­(III) and Am­(III) ionic radii were also determined by Cross, but the very small difference between the two actinides, 0.003 Å, makes these data not relevant. Given that the ionic radii of the common lanthanides (Ce­(III), Pr­(III), Nd­(III)) are identical in both of the references, the one reported by Shannon was chosen for lanthanides and the one reported by David was chosen for actinides. It highlights a change in behavior between the beginning (Ce, Pr, Nd) and the middle (Sm, Gd) of the lanthanide series. The variation of the slope is quite important, and an inversion of the M–Owater distances compared to M–Ooxalate is observed. Indeed, for light lanthanides, the M–Owater distances are longer than the M–Ooxygen. In the gadolinium and samarium oxalates, this trend is inverted, and all the M–O distances are smaller. For this structurally similar series, both the M–Ooxalate and M–Owater distances increase with the ionic radii but in a nonlinear fashion. The break slope in between samarium and neodymium reflects a strong increase in the bond strength for heavier lanthanides. Moreover the water molecules look more sensitive to this change than the oxalate ions.

Looking at the M–Owater and M–Ooxalate distances for plutonium, it seems to act as light lanthanides (cerium, praseodymium, neodymium) with M–Ooxalate length smaller than or equal to the M–Owater, whereas for americium the inversion has already occurred, since the M–Owater distances are smaller than the M–Ooxalate bond lengths. So, the observed transition in the lanthanide series is likely to exist for actinides. This trend has to be confirmed as the two types of distances are in fact quite similar for plutonium. It would be interesting to complete the trend and to confirm the sensed increasing bond strength along the actinide series with data from isomorphous structure, UIII­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O and NpIII­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, but these compounds are difficult to synthesize, as they require oxygen-free crystal growth methods.

elements.content: Considering the ionic radii, lanthanides appear to be bad analogues. The comparison of the distances for very close ionic radii (R Nd(III) = 1.163 Å, R Pu(III) = 1.176 Å, R Am(III) = 1.167 Å) confirms the deviation between the two series. The two M–Owater and M–Ooxalate average distances of the neodymium crystals are longer than those of the actinides despite its smaller ionic radii, R Nd(III) < R Am(III) < R Pu(III).

elements.content: Looking at the a and c unit cell parameters, the transition between the light and mid-series lanthanides as well as the differences between the actinide and the lanthanide series are also observed but to a smaller extent than described on the basis of the M–O distances (). Indeed, the lattice parameters represent global parameters of the whole solid whereas the coordination sphere distances characterize the behavior at a nanostructural scale and reveal more information and details which could explain the amplitude difference. The b lattice parameter acts differently from a and c. The b parameter, perpendicular to the layers of the two-dimensional structure, (i) is less influenced by the ionic radii of the metallic cation and (ii) depends on the interlayer space content, such as the number of free water molecules, in the different structures. Its variation is thus not intuitive and is difficult to discuss.

elements.content: Previous studies assume that ionicity is the predominant character of both lanthanide and actinide bonding, but it appears that the notion of ionic and steric factors as the largest contributors to the chemistry of the f-block elements may not be entirely true for the 5f-block compounds. The variation between actinide and lanthanide oxalate compounds was already discussed for mixed U­(IV)–M­(III) oxalate with M = Nd­(III) or Pu­(III).

Spectroscopy Studies

All single-phase solids (single crystals for lanthanide oxalates and precipitates for Pu(III) and Am(IIII) oxalates) were studied by IR spectroscopy. The spectra are presented , and the main vibration wave numbers are gathered in .

elements.clean_text: 11  Infrared spectra of lanthanide(III) and actinide(III) oxalates, M2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, with M = Pr (B), Nd (C), Sm (D), Gd (E), Pu (F), and Am (A).

elements.content: According to previous studies on oxalate compounds, the band near 790 cm–1 is attributed to the O–C–O deformation, δ­(O–C–O). The C–O elongation vibrations are expected at 1310–1350 (doublet), 1510, and 1620 cm–1. They are characteristic of the ν11(CO) symmetric, ν1(CO) symmetric, and ν5(CO) antisymmetric vibration modes, respectively. The peaks at 920 and 850 cm–1, almost invisible in the IR spectra, correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric C–C stretching modes. These bands as well as that of ν1s(CO) (1480 cm–1) are supposed to be forbidden in IR spectroscopy. Nevertheless, they can be made out with a very weak intensity on actinide oxalate spectra. These observations are probably related to some symmetry defects within the crystal structures enhanced by the actinide specific activities. The structures being similar, the IR spectra are nearly identical with very small shifts of some bands. The IR δ12(OCO) and ν11s(CO) bands’ sensitivity to variation of the metallic cation nature and the ionic radii is not significant. Concerning the ν5as(CO) elongation, there is no obvious shift for light lanthanides (Pr and Nd) and actinides (Pu and Am). The shift becomes significant, 4 cm–1, for smaller lanthanides such as samarium and gadolinium. This trend is in agreement with metal–oxygen distances in the coordination sphere and the transition within the lanthanide series discussed earlier.
elements.clean_text: According to previous studies on oxalate compounds, the band near 790 cm-1 is attributed to the O-C-O deformation, δ(O-C-O). The C-O elongation vibrations are expected at 1310-1350 (doublet), 1510, and 1620 cm-1. They are characteristic of the ν11(CO) symmetric, ν1(CO) symmetric, and ν5(CO) antisymmetric vibration modes, respectively. The peaks at 920 and 850 cm-1, almost invisible in the IR spectra, correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric C-C stretching modes. These bands as well as that of ν1s(CO) (1480 cm-1) are supposed to be forbidden in IR spectroscopy. Nevertheless, they can be made out with a very weak intensity on actinide oxalate spectra. These observations are probably related to some symmetry defects within the crystal structures enhanced by the actinide specific activities. The structures being similar, the IR spectra are nearly identical with very small shifts of some bands. The IR δ12(OCO) and ν11s(CO) bands' sensitivity to variation of the metallic cation nature and the ionic radii is not significant. Concerning the ν5as(CO) elongation, there is no obvious shift for light lanthanides (Pr and Nd) and actinides (Pu and Am). The shift becomes significant, 4 cm-1, for smaller lanthanides such as samarium and gadolinium. This trend is in agreement with metal-oxygen distances in the coordination sphere and the transition within the lanthanide series discussed earlier.

The same study was carried out by Raman spectroscopy. The spectra are presented , and the vibration wave numbers are given in . In contrast to IR spectroscopy, with a spectrometer equipped with a superhead, it is possible to make the analysis on one selected single crystal for each oxalate compound, M2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O (M = Pr (B), Nd (C), Sm (D), Gd (E), Pu (F), Am (A)). The overall shapes of the different spectra are identical except for samarium. Under 532 nm laser radiation, this element produces fluorescent signature with two large bands at 970 and 1960 cm–1. These bands hide the band at 910 cm–1, but the two others at 500 and 1480 cm–1 are still visible and workable. It was not possible to change the laser wavelength because of the superhead specifically designed for 532 nm laser. The bands around 500 cm–1 are attributed to the oxalate deformations (δ3(OCO) and δ6(OCO)). The twisted δ12(OCO) mode observed at 790 cm–1 with IR spectroscopy becomes forbidden in Raman spectroscopy. On the contrary, the C–C stretching mode invisible on the IR spectra presents a characteristic signature on the Raman spectra near 910 cm–1. Concerning the C–O bond, the stretching band at 1480 cm–1, nearly switched off in IR (depending on the compounds but particularly visible for actinides and their radiolytic disorder), becomes dominant. It is worth noting that the doubling of the ν1s(CO) vibration mode is particularly surprising as only one vibration mode is theoretically allowed under the Ci symmetry. The presence of two bands in the 1460–1490 cm–1 region was already described in the literature, and different explanations were proposed, such as combination of ν5(CO) + ν9(CO) at 1460 cm–1 or a supplementary bond due to the resonance of O–C–O rocking motion δ8(OCO) (2ν8). Some studies suggest the presence of free oxalates in the system leading to the additional band. However, it would be surprising to observe such a contribution of free oxalate with the previous ethanol/water washing. The most reasonable hypothesis is the presence of non-equivalent oxalates within the structure. At the foot of this double band, a shoulder corresponds to the ν2(CO) and ν3s(CO) vibrations. Beyond 1500 cm–1, two vibration modes, ν5as(CO) and νas(CO–H), at respectively 1630 and 1710 cm–1, are recognized on some spectra. They are supposed to be forbidden, leading to very weak intensities and bad resolution. The weak band observed at 1080 cm–1 on the Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O is specific of nitrate groups. The specific crystal growth method used for this system (high nitric concentration) probably leads to free nitrate anions adsorbed on the crystal surface despite the washing of the crystals.

elements.clean_text: 12  Raman spectra of lanthanide(III) and actinide(III) oxalates, M2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, with M = Pr (B), Nd (C), Sm (D), Gd (E), Pu (F), and Am (A).

elements.content: The main vibration wave numbers of the different actinide and lanthanide oxalates are reported in . The entire range spectrum seems sensitive to the cation nature, and all the bands are shifted. Although the intensities and the widths of the bands at 500 and 930 cm–1 are difficult to determine precisely, it seems that a transition occurs between the gadolinium oxalate and the other light lanthanide oxalates. This transition appears quite clearly by examination of the doublet at 1470–1480 cm–1, which is strongly shifted for Gd2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O compared to the other isotypes. In all the compounds, the vibration of the band at 1484 cm–1 within the doublet does not shift with the variation of ionic radii (except for gadolinium). The evolution of this vibration frequency is unexpected, since Morris et al. studied lanthanide oxalate and observed an evolution of the frequency of this band with a modification of the ionic radii. Nevertheless, the lack of XRD on the solids studied by these authors establishes a doubt concerning the structure of the oxalate; particularly the use of sodium oxalate leads to possible formation of a double Na-Ln-oxalate. On the contrary, the vibration mode at 1470 cm–1 depends on the ionic radii. Considering the lanthanide solids only, the wavenumber increases from 1470 cm–1 for praseodymium to 1477 cm–1 for gadolinium oxalate. It is well-known that when the ionic radii of the cation decrease for similar oxalate structure, the bond frequencies increase. The same trend is observed for actinide oxalates with 1475 and 1477 cm–1 for respectively plutonium and americium. The comparison of the two series is particularly interesting. Considering ionic interactions only, with an ionic radii of 1.176 Å, the vibration frequency of Pu­(III) oxalate is expected between 1470 and 1473 cm–1, frequencies of Pr­(III) and Nd­(III) solids with respectively 1.179 and 1.163 Å ionic radii. Nevertheless, the ν1s(CO) vibration of the Pu­(III) appears at 1475 cm–1. This trend seems to be confirmed with the vibrational frequencies of the americium oxalate (R Am(III) = 1.167 Å), 1477 cm–1, equivalent to the gadolinium oxalate one (R Gd(III) = 1.107 Å). This increase of the ν1s(CO) vibration frequency independently of the ionic radii reveals a change in the bond energy and a variation of the metal–oxalate coordination. The C–O bond energy seems to vary by electronic delocalization toward the cation. The Raman investigations are thus in agreement with the comparison of the coordination sphere distances. The C–O bond energy increases while the distances between the two atoms decrease which demonstrates an enhance of the bond-strength of actinide­(III) complexes compared to similar lanthanide­(III) complexes. Although this seems in agreement with an increase of the covalent contribution to the bonding of actinide­(III) complexes relative to lanthanide­(III) surrogates, it remains quite difficult to define precisely what is causing the shorter coordination sphere distances than one can expect on the ionic radii consideration. On the one hand, theoretical calculation of the covalence character, referred as the electron density in the internuclear region, may differ whether it is considered as resulting from atomic orbital mixing or from orbital overlapping between bonding atoms. On the other hand, the μ-bridging of carboxylate functional groups of the oxalate ligands leads to a two-dimensional structure within which the μ-bridging oxalates are all related to each other that precludes the consideration of a unique isolated coordination sphere and makes calculations more difficult and the results not reliable.

In all the compounds, the vibration of the band at 1484 cm-1 within the doublet does not shift with the variation of ionic radii (except for gadolinium). The evolution of this vibration frequency is unexpected, since Morris et al. studied lanthanide oxalate and observed an evolution of the frequency of this band with a modification of the ionic radii. Nevertheless, the lack of XRD on the solids studied by these authors establishes a doubt concerning the structure of the oxalate; particularly the use of sodium oxalate leads to possible formation of a double Na-Ln-oxalate. It is well-known that when the ionic radii of the cation decrease for similar oxalate structure, the bond frequencies increase. The same trend is observed for actinide oxalates with 1475 and 1477 cm-1 for respectively plutonium and americium. The comparison of the two series is particularly interesting. Considering ionic interactions only, with an ionic radii of 1.176 Å, the vibration frequency of Pu(III) oxalate is expected between 1470 and 1473 cm-1, frequencies of Pr(III) and Nd(III) solids with respectively 1.179 and 1.163 Å ionic radii. Nevertheless, the ν1s(CO) vibration of the Pu(III) appears at 1475 cm-1. This trend seems to be confirmed with the vibrational frequencies of the americium oxalate (R Am(III) = 1.167 Å), 1477 cm-1, equivalent to the gadolinium oxalate one (R Gd(III) = 1.107 Å). This increase of the ν1s(CO) vibration frequency independently of the ionic radii reveals a change in the bond energy and a variation of the metal-oxalate coordination. The C-O bond energy seems to vary by electronic delocalization toward the cation. The Raman investigations are thus in agreement with the comparison of the coordination sphere distances. The C-O bond energy increases while the distances between the two atoms decrease which demonstrates an enhance of the bond-strength of actinide(III) complexes compared to similar lanthanide(III) complexes. Although this seems in agreement with an increase of the covalent contribution to the bonding of actinide(III) complexes relative to lanthanide(III) surrogates, it remains quite difficult to define precisely what is causing the shorter coordination sphere distances than one can expect on the ionic radii consideration. On the one hand, theoretical calculation of the covalence character, referred as the electron density in the internuclear region, may differ whether it is considered as resulting from atomic orbital mixing or from orbital overlapping between bonding atoms. On the other hand, the μ-bridging of carboxylate functional groups of the oxalate ligands leads to a two-dimensional structure within which the μ-bridging oxalates are all related to each other that precludes the consideration of a unique isolated coordination sphere and makes calculations more difficult and the results not reliable.

elements.content: With an adapted crystal growth method, americium­(III) oxalate single crystals, Am2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​4H2O, were synthesized for the first time. Their structure determination completes the previously very poor description of americium structures. The Am­(III) oxalate is isostructural to Pu­(III) and Ln­(III) oxalates described previously. This second isomorphous structure, after Pu2­(C2O4)3­(H2O)6·​nH2O, in the actinide series has allowed us to see some trends concerning the coordination behavior of the 5f-elements family and compare them to the lanthanides. Raman and IR spectroscopies, used to characterize the metal–oxalate bonding, as well as the coordination sphere distances, reveal differences along and between the two f-element series. Concerning lanthanide compounds, light (Pr­(III), Nd­(III)) and heavy (Sm­(III), Gd­(III)) cations do not behave similarly, highlighting the presence of a break. This break seems to exist for actinides as well and probably occurs between Pu­(III) and Am­(III). Examination of the M–O distances reveals a higher bond strength by crossing the f-blocks series or comparing the lanthanides and actinides series. This could be related to a modification in the bond type that may gain in covalency, but at this step it the work it remains difficult to conclude with certainty on this aspect.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

With an adapted crystal growth method, americium(III) oxalate single crystals, Am2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅4H2O, were synthesized for the first time. Their structure determination completes the previously very poor description of americium structures. The Am(III) oxalate is isostructural to Pu(III) and Ln(III) oxalates described previously. This second isomorphous structure, after Pu2(C2O4)3(H2O)6⋅nH2O, in the actinide series has allowed us to see some trends concerning the coordination behavior of the 5f-elements family and compare them to the lanthanides. Raman and IR spectroscopies, used to characterize the metal-oxalate bonding, as well as the coordination sphere distances, reveal differences along and between the two f-element series. Concerning lanthanide compounds, light (Pr(III), Nd(III)) and heavy (Sm(III), Gd(III)) cations do not behave similarly, highlighting the presence of a break. This break seems to exist for actinides as well and probably occurs between Pu(III) and Am(III). Examination of the M-O distances reveals a higher bond strength by crossing the f-blocks series or comparing the lanthanides and actinides series. This could be related to a modification in the bond type that may gain in covalency, but at this step it the work it remains difficult to conclude with certainty on this aspect.
